question: A patient presents with suprapubic pain, dysuria, and frequency of urination. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 55-year-old male came with complaints of abdominal pain, high-grade fever with altered mental state, dysuria, and hematuria. His urine DR report shows numerous pus cells, nitrite positive, and few red blood cells. The physician diagnoses him with a case of urinary tract infection. Which of the following methods of urine collection has the lowest risk of contamination?
Which of these can not be used to differentiate pre-renal from renal failure?
A patient presents with loin pain and hematuria. What is the first line of investigation?

A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency (ER) with colicky lower abdominal pain and hematuria. The attending doctor makes the preliminary diagnosis of urinary tract calculus. To confirm his diagnosis, the first radiological modality is:

A 40-year-old man has had increasing lower extremity edema for the past three weeks. On examination, his blood pressure (BP) is 135/90 mmHg and pitting edema up till his knees. Laboratory results show serum creatinine level of 1.2 mg/dl and urea nitrogen of 16 mg/dl. 24-hour urine protein of 7.4 grams. Serum ASO, ANA, HIV, and ANCA are negative. Complement levels are also normal. On renal biopsy, there is a diffuse uniform thickening of the glomerular basement membranes. Immunofluorescence shows granular IgG and C3 basement membrane deposits. In the given scenario, electron microscopy would most likely reveal which finding?

answers.option: Mesangial IgG and C3 electron dense deposits
Sub-endothelial electron dense deposits with duplication of basement membranes
Sub-epithelial IgG and C3 deposits electron dense deposits

question: A 48-year-old male with a history of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) and obesity has noticed recent fatigue, bilateral pedal edema, and periorbital puffiness. Urine D/R shows proteinuria and fatty casts. If we plan renal biopsy what will be the histological result?
A 55-year-old patient is admitted with a massive gastrointestinal (GI) bleed. The patient is at risk for what type of acute kidney injury?

A 58-year-old man noticed blood in his urine and consulted his family physician. On examination, he appears to be in good health. Laboratory results show mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia, and hematuria. X-ray abdomen followed by computed tomography (CT) scan revealed an irregular mass 6 cm in diameter occupying most of his left kidney. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old child presented to the emergency department (ED) with complaints of abdominal pain and vomiting. He was previously healthy but has a history of easy fatigability, weight loss, and increased thirst. On examination, heart rate is 145/min, respiratory rate 50/min, temperature 98F, and the chest is clear on auscultation. On investigations, arterial blood gases (ABGs) showed pH 7.2, and HCO3 12 meq/l. The random blood sugar is 360 mg/dl. What is the likely diagnosis?

A 6-year-old girl develops pitting edema in her ankles and legs. Urinalysis show 3+ proteinuria. The urinary sediment contains no inflammatory cells or red blood cells. Serum levels of blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine are normal. She recovers completely after a course of corticosteroids. Light microscopy of a renal biopsy specimen from this girl would most likely demonstrate which of the following changes?

answers.option: Electron-dense immune deposits in the capillary basement membranes
Loss of microvilli by the tubular lining cells

question: A 70-year-old female came to the emergency for dysuria and hematuria. Urine D/R showed numerous pus cells and proteinuria. X-ray showed an asymmetrical contracted kidney with blunting of the calyceal system. She was diagnosed with reflux nephropathy. Which one of the following complications is associated with reflux nephropathy?
A child was recently diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome on renal biopsy. Her mother asked how she can identify a relapse. Sign of relapse is:

answers.option: Swelling in legs, hands, face or abdomen

question: A couple married for three years was unable to conceive a child. Laboratory reports for fertility analysis were found to be normal for both the husband (age = 35 years) and wife (age = 29 years) with no known comorbidities. What procedure will you advise them to consider?
A middle-aged female was advised ultrasound KUB for recurrent abdominal pain. All of the following are the clinical indications for ultrasound except:

answers.option: Diagnosis of renal and bladder masses

question: A middle-aged man with a history of gross hematuria for 2 weeks. He had an ultrasound KUB which gave suspicion of a left renal mass lesion. Which is the next imaging modality for confirmation and staging of the renal mass lesion?

answers.option: CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast

question: What is the most common cause of chronic kidney disease?

Parents brought a 7-year-old child to emergency with a history of passing cola-colored urine since morning and severe headache for the last 2 hours. There is a history of skin infection 15 days back, which was treated by some local general practitioner (GP). Which is the most important vital sign examination in this child?
Dietary restriction in nephrotic syndrome includes a low-sodium diet and:

Laboratory diagnosis is based on colony counts following culture, which reflect the concentration of organisms in urine and hence the likelihood that the bacteria have grown arise from a urinary tract infection (UTI) rather than contamination. What would be the minimum urine culture colony count necessary to make a clinical diagnosis of UTI?
Which of these is accurate about simple kidney cysts?
Which of these features is not a part of adult-onset polycystic kidney disease?
What is the most common presentation of renal cell carcinoma?
Which of these stones are radiolucent?
Ultrasound shows a bright, highly reflective lesion in the right kidney. The most likely diagnosis is:
You're collecting a urine sample on a patient who is experiencing proteinuria due to nephrotic syndrome. As the doctor, you know the urine will appear:
What is the main cardiovascular complication in chronic kidney disease patients with dialysis?

A 23-year-old female, who is a known case of anxiety disorder, begins hyperventilating while waiting to see her psychiatrist. The doctor's assistant immediately makes her breathe in a paper bag and she improves. If an arterial blood gas was taken while she was hyperventilating it would have probably which of the following findings?

answers.option: Normal findings on arterial blood gas

question: A 67-year-old male who is a known case of chronic renal failure (CRF) comes for his follow-up visit to the nephrologist. His creatinine is stable, however, his bicarbonate is 15 mEq/L. In order to prevent metabolic bone disease, his serum bicarbonate levels should be maintained at what level?
An ultrasound scan of a pregnant woman revealed a large bladder in a fetus (megacystis). It is also associated with dilation of the renal pelvis. What is the embryological basis of this anomaly?

A 36-year-old female presents to the emergency with a high-grade fever with chills, increased urination, and one episode of hematuria. On examination, she has tenderness in the right lumbar region. What is the most likely cause of her illness?

A 65-year-old man presents with hematuria, microcytic, hypochromic anemia, and right-sided hydronephrosis. CT scan reveals a mass in the right renal pelvis. The most likely diagnosis, in this case, would be.

A 55-year-old male comes with complaints of abdominal pain, high-grade fever with altered mental state, dysuria, and hematuria. His urine analysis report shows numerous pus cells, nitrite positive, and few red blood cells. He is diagnosed with a urinary tract infection. What would be the most common causative agent?

A 56-year-old patient who is a known case of diabetes mellitus type 2 presented with recurrent episodes, of burning micturition and pain lower abdomen. Which of the following investigation is pertinent at this stage?

A 27-year-old woman presents with complaints of an increased urinary frequency with dysuria for the past 4 days. A urinalysis reveals sp. gr. 1.014, pH 7.5, no glucose, no protein, no blood, nitrite positive, and many WBC's. She has a serum creatinine of 0.9 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is not an indication for dialysis in acute renal failure?

A 4-year-old boy is diagnosed as a case of nephrotic syndrome, first attack, and is on the appropriate dose of prednisone for ten days. His urinary protein creatinine ratio is <0.2. What is the most appropriate classification of this child?

A 30-year-old male presented, to the outpatient department with a high-grade fever and sore throat for the last 3 days. For one day he noticed blood in urine and facial puffiness. On examination, his blood pressure was 150/90mmHg with mild pedal and facial edema. What are the likely diagnoses?
Microalbuminuria is defined as when the albumin excretion is noted with what level in normal urine volume?

A 65-year-old man notices blood in his urine. On examination, there is pain and tenderness in his left flank. A peripheral smear and complete blood count show mild microcytic, hypochromic anemia. A CT scan shows an irregular renal mass measuring 4.2 cm in diameter occupying the upper half of the left kidney. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 9-year-old boy presents with nausea, headaches, and dizziness. He has recently recovered from tonsillitis. On examination, there is facial edema and blood pressure of 170/110 mmHg. A 24-hour urine collection measures 400ml. Urinalysis shows hematuria. Which of the following would be the most appropriate glomerular pathology in this case?
In a patient with non- dialysis-dependent chronic kidney disease (CKD), which management is known to reduce vascular events?
Which of the following condition cannot cause normal anion gap metabolic acidosis?

A 62-year-old man presents with a history of smoky urine for the last one week. On examination, there are no positive findings. A urine examination shows pH 5.5, 2+ blood, no protein, and no glucose. Urine cytology reveals atypical cells. Cystoscopy is normal. He has a 60 pack-year history of cigarette smoking. Which of the following is the most likely possibility in this case?
Orthostatic proteinuria is seen in which of the following conditions?

A 50-year-male present with generalized weakness his investigations show creatinine of 3mg/dl ultrasound abdomen shows bilateral small kidneys. What is the most common physical finding in chronic renal failure?

A 55-year-old man presents with generalized edema and ascites. Laboratory tests show: a total serum protein of 5.2g/dl (range: 5.5-8.0g/dl), albumin of 1.9g/dl (range: 3.5-5.5g/dl), and serum cholesterol of 540mg/dl. 24-hour urine collection reveals 4.8gms of protein loss. Urine contains many hyaline casts but no RBCs or WBCs. Immuno-fluorescence on renal biopsy shows granular sub-epithelial deposits along the glomerular basement membranes. Which one of the following would be the most appropriate glomerular pathology involved?
Which of the following antibodies are found in focal segmental glomerulosclerosis?

A 7-year-old girl presents with puffiness around her eyes. Examination shows a blood pressure of 100/60 mmHg. Laboratory investigations show serum creatinine and urea nitrogen are within normal ranges. Urinalysis shows 4+ proteinuria, no blood, glucose, or ketones. The 24-hour urine protein content of 3.9g. The child's condition improves after a course of corticosteroid therapy. Which of the following is the best option to describe her condition?

answers.option: Nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease
Chronic renal failure due to dense deposit disease
Nephrotic syndrome due to membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis
Nephrotic syndrome caused by cresentric glomerulonephritis
Nephritic syndrome due to post-infectious glomerulonephritis

question: A 25-year-old woman with acute pyelonephritis was treated with oral ciprofloxacin. On day 8 of antibiotic treatment, the patient developed a maculopapular rash, low-grade fever, and eosinophilia. Serum creatinine was 2 mg/dl (baseline: 0.7 mg/dl). What would be the diagnosis?
What is the treatment for hypernatremia in patients with chronic liver disease with ascites?

A 22-year-old woman presents with swelling of the legs. On urinalysis, there was increased proteinuria. She is diagnosed to have tubulointerstitial nephritis. It could have been drug-induced. It is characterized by which of the following?

answers.option: Increased glomerular filtration rate and oliguria
Appearance of symptoms after about two weeks of exposure
Dose dependent severity of the disease

question: Which of the following is the hallmark of nephritic syndrome?

answers.option: Hypertension with salt and water retreatment

question: A 50-year-old man has noted passing darker urine for the past week. On physical examination, there are no abnormal findings. A urinalysis shows pH 5.5, specific gravity 1.013, 2+ blood, no protein, and no glucose. Urine cytology is performed and there are atypical uroepithelial cells seen. A urologist performs a cystoscopy, but no mucosal lesions are noted. He has a 60 pack-year history of smoking cigarettes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

A 30-year-old man has noted puffiness around his eyes and swelling of his feet for the past 2 weeks. On physical examination, his blood pressure is 155/95 mm Hg. Urine microscopic examination reveals oval fat bodies. Which of the following conditions is he most likely to have?
What is the most important parameter for the analysis of arterial blood gases (ABGs)?

answers.option: Calculate the range of the compensatory response

question: A patient on dialysis for chronic kidney disease is likely to have what complication?

A 40-year-old male patient has presented with decreased urinary output of 5 days duration after he has been bitten by a snake. Which of the following investigations should be performed initially in this patient with acute renal failure?
What is the least likely cause of a urinary tract infection?

A 60-year-old male, known case of diabetes mellitus, presents to the outpatient department, with complaints of uncontrolled blood sugar and bilateral pedal edema, gradually increasing for 4 months. On examination anemia and pitting edema is present. Laboratory results show hemoglobin: 10.1 gm/dl, total leukocyte count (TLC), and platelets: normal, urea: 60 mg/dl, serum creatinine: 2.0 mg/dl, eGFR < 60 ml/min/1.73m2. The most appropriate first investigation will be:
What is the commonest presentation of Wilms tumor?
A 24-year-old patient presents with edema and hypertension is diagnosed with nephrotic syndrome. It can develop as a result of a number of renal injuries. What is it characterized by?

The hydrostatic pressure in Bowman's capsule is 18 mmHg, the hydrostatic pressure in glomerular capillaries is 60 mmHg, and colloidal osmotic pressure in the glomerular capillaries is 32 mmHg. What should be the net pressure to drive glomerular filtration?

A 33-year-old patient presents with bilateral swelling of the legs. On a detailed urine report, she was found to have increased proteinuria. She was diagnosed to have acute kidney injury. What features would suggest immune involvement in acute kidney injury?

A 66-year-old woman complaining of dysuria, polyuria, intermittent gross hematuria, and chronic low back pain. She had a history of urinary tract infections and pyelonephritis of the kidney. Urinalysis revealed urine sedimentation, a pH of 9.0, leukocyte esterase positive, nitrite positive, WBC 90-100/HPF, RBC 60-80/HPF. A KUB radiograph showed large calcifications in both kidneys. What is the most likely composition of these calcifications?

A group of medical students wants to conduct research on the serum and urine parameters of patients with minimal change disease. Which of the following laboratory test findings is most likely to be consistently present in these subjects?

answers.option: Renal tubular epithelial cells and casts

question: A 43-year-old man complains of increased fatigue and malaise for 3 weeks. His blood pressure is 150/95 mmHg. On examination, there is pitting edema of the lower limbs extending up to the knees. Urinalysis shows no glucose, blood, ketones, nitrite, or urobilinogen. Microscopic examination of urine exhibits no RBC or WBC. 24-hour urine protein is 4.2 gm. Serum creatinine and urea are high (3.5 mg/dL and 38 mg/dL respectively). Serum HBsAg is positive. Which of the following pathological condition is the possible diagnosis?
Which of the following is the best diagnostic test for ureteric stone?

A 29-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with the complaint of joint pain in small fingers. There were no other symptoms or signs upon examination. What is the probable diagnosis of this condition?
A 5-year-old child was brought to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain and hematuria. Upon examination, the child had a flank palpable mass. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following should not be given to a patient of hypernatremia?
Which of the following is the most common risk factor for dialysis and transplant?

A newborn baby is brought to the outpatient department with the complaint of constant urine dribbling. Upon ultrasound, there is bilateral hydronephrosis and the bladder is full. What is the probable diagnosis?

A 10-year-old male presents with palpable purpura in the lower extremities and buttocks area. Investigations reveal a decreased glomerular filtration rate (GFR) with a nephritic picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A 20-year-old male presents with a history of an upper respiratory infection followed by gross hematuria, 1 day later. Urine D/R shows increased RBCs, RBC casts, and proteinuria. His renal function test shows increased creatinine. Renal biopsy shows IgA deposition in the mesangium. What would be the most likely diagnosis?

A 10-year-old male is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of periorbital puffiness and pedal edema. His urine analysis shows proteinuria, absence of RBCs and casts. You suspect minimal change disease. What would the renal biopsy findings in this patient be?

answers.option: Sclerosis of segments of some glomeruli
Dense deposits on subepithelial surface of basement membrane

question: A 25 year-old-male presents with a reduced urinary output. He has a history of gouty arthritis for which he has taken indomethacin. Investigations reveal a Cr=2.5 mg/dl, and urine D/R shows WBC casts. What is the likely diagnosis?
A middle-aged male presented to the outpatient department with complaints of epistaxis, hemoptysis and dark colored urine. Which of the following is the most likely condition?
In acute kidney injury, what contributes to metabolic acidosis?

answers.option: Too few hydrogen ions, which increases the blood pH
Potassium movement from extracellular to intracellular fluid
Excess sodium conservation by renal tubules
Renal tubules inability to generate bicarbonate

question: Which of the following cannot cause acute kidney injury?

A couple married for four years was unable to conceive a pregnancy. A detailed analysis of the sperms of the husband revealed azoospermia. They were suggested to go for artificial insemination by a fertility specialist. Which type of procedure would best suit the couple?
Which of the following is considered the gold standard for the treatment of benign prostate hyperplasia (BPH)?
Which of the following is the initial investigation in a patient with suspected ureteric calculi?
A 17-year-old girl decided to go on a starvation diet. After 1 week of starving herself, which of the following substances would most likely be found in her urine?
A patient presents to the emergency room with complaints of diarrhea and vomiting for one day. He is semi-conscious and severely dehydrated. What is the first-line management in this patient?
Which of the following functions is the kidney not responsible for?
Patients with diabetes mellitus have urine with which of the following characteristics?

answers.option: Decreased volume and decreased specific gravity
Decreased volume and increased specific gravity
Increased volume and decreased specific gravity
Same volume and same specific gravity
Increased volume and increased specific gravity

question: A 55-year-old male with COPD presents to the clinic with increased severity of shortness of breath. His immediate arterial blood gases show respiratory acidosis. What is the first step in the interpretation of arterial blood gases?
In a patient with severe dehydration, which of the following organs most commonly becomes non-functional almost immediately?

A 15-year-old girl with no known prior comorbidities presented to the emergency department with abdominal pain, vomiting, and shortness of breath for one day. She has mild tenderness in her epigastrium. She is dehydrated and hypotensive. Her blood sugar level is 450 mg/dL. What is the most common cause of a high anion gap metabolic acidosis?
What may patients with renal failure present with?

A 17-year-old boy came presents to the clinic with recurrent hematuria for the past 3 months. He also states that he feels febrile and has a mild body ache. On examination, there is no anemia, edema, congested throat, or organomegaly. There is no similar personal or family history of a similar illness and no other chronic illnesses. Initial investigations reveal normal hemoglobin, albumin, urea, creatinine, and alanine aminotransferase. A urine drug report shows grade-1 parenchymal changes. During an autoimmune workup, the presence of anti-nuclear antibodies was positive, and 2+ fine speckled with normal anti-ds-DNA and complement levels. What should be the next appropriate investigation to establish a diagnosis?
Which of the following is the best treatment for euvolemic hyponatremia?
Many diuretics are known to cause hypokalemia. Which one of the following drugs causes hyperkalemia?

A 50-year-old male patient with a known case of diabetes presented to the outpatient department. His laboratory investigations showed hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperkalemia. Which of the following can be the cause of these metabolic abnormalities?
Which investigation will be done on a woman with a complaint of urinary incontinence?

answers.option: Ultrasound bladder with pre and post void volumes

question: A 50-year-old male patient with a known case of diabetes presented to the outpatient department. His laboratory investigations showed hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and hyperkalemia. He was diagnosed with chronic kidney failure and now complained of shortness of breath, lack of energy, and pale skin. What could be the cause of his anemia?

While operating on a man after road traffic accident, doctor found scarring on a kidney. Scarring of the kidney along with dilation in a completely asymptomatic patient can be found in which of the following conditions?

A 23-year-old female presents to the outpatient clinic with complaints of increased frequency, urgency, and dysuria for the past 2 weeks. Her history is also significant for suprapubic discomfort and her laboratory reports show increased nitrites and leukocyte count. What is the single most likely diagnosis?

A 27-year-old man who lived alone in a studio died suddenly. Upon post-mortem examination, several raised yellow abscesses on the kidney surface were seen. Which of the following diseases is associated with rapid loss of renal function over days to weeks?
A 70-year-old male is having urinary incontinence and nocturia. He also complains of dribbling of urine and hematuria. Which investigation should be done to rule out bladder outlet obstruction?

A person who is diabetic for many years develops anemia, hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, fatigue, and body aches. His previous medical history reveals that he has been diagnosed with osteoporosis along with chronic renal failure for which he has been on dialysis for the past 4 months. Which of the following correctly describes his condition?

A patient presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of severe pain in the loin region along with oliguria, hematuria, and burning micturition. Which of the following investigations is considered a gold standard for detecting a kidney stone?

A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic with a complaint of bleeding and pain during and after urination. He was treated for a urinary tract infection several times in the past. Which of the following can be the cause of this condition if the pain is radiating towards the perineum?

A 30-year-old female presents to the outpatient department with complaints of urinary incontinence, fever, and painful micturition. She also complained that she sometimes sees the pus coming out along with the urine. What will be the first investigation that can be done in this case?

answers.option: Mid stream urine culture and microscopy

question: Which of the following is not present in oral rehydration therapy?

A 29-year-old woman presents to the outpatient department with complaints of hematuria and frothy urine. She also gives a history of joint pain in small fingers, knees, and hip but there is no deformity upon examination in any of these joints. She sometimes feels irritated by bright lights. What is the probable diagnosis of this condition?

A 30-year-old female patient presented to the outpatient department with a complaint of hematuria. She had a history of alopecia, photosensitivity, and oral ulcers. She seemed very conscious about a butterfly-shaped rash on her cheeks. Upon investigation, she had a proteinuria > 0.5 g/24 hours. Which of the following correctly describes the cause of her renal condition?
Which of the following can be used as a first-line agent in the treatment of bladder carcinoma in situ?

answers.option: Trans urethral resection of bladder tumor.

question: A person presents to the outpatient department with a complaint of urinary incontinence and burning micturition. After a detailed investigation, a digital rectal examination is performed on which his prostate gland is found to be stony hard. Which of the following can be the most probable diagnosis in this case?

A 32-year-old case of diabetes mellitus and using alcohol occasionally, presented with loose stools, watery in consistency for 3 days. He has around 10-12 of these episodes every day. On examination, he was dehydrated, with around 200 ml of urine output in 24 hours. Initial investigation showed an Hb of 14.8 mg/dL, TLC 11.2 x 10³/L, platelet count of 324x 10³/L, K⁺ 9.4 mEq/L, HCO₃⁻ 18, Urea: 94. Among the mentioned laboratory parameters which of the following is a highly indicative marker for hemodialysis?

A 24-year-old female presented with decreased urination and hematuria for 2 days. She has been unwell for the past 15 days with a severe sore throat and high-grade fever with chills. On examination, she has a blood pressure of 150/100 mmHg, pulse of 94/min, and temperature of 100°F. Systemic and general physical examinations were unremarkable. Which of the following urinary casts is most specific for her illness?

A 50-year-old male is admitted to the medical ward with a history of abdominal distention and pedal edema. He is diagnosed as a case of chronic liver disease (cirrhosis). A complete blood count (CBC) shows a Hb of 10 mg/dL, WBC 3x10 mm³, platelet count 105x10 mm³, serum albumin 2.7mg/dl, prothrombin time 18 sec, (normal: 11-14 sec). Serum sodium is 122 mEq/L, serum K⁺ 3.6 mg/L, creatinine 1.1 mg/dl. What is the cause of hyponatremia in this patient according to history and physical examination?

A 60-year-old male known diabetic for 8 years, taking oral hypoglycemic drugs is admitted to the medical intensive care unit (ICU) with an altered level of consciousness. There is no history of fever. There are no signs of meningeal irritation. Investigation: complete blood count (CBC) 11 mg/dL, WBC 5X10⁹ mm³, platelet count of 162 x10⁹ mm³. Random blood sugar (RBS) of 590 mg/dL, creatinine 1.2 mg/dL, serum sodium 168mg/dL, and a serum potassium of 3.9 mg/dl. For treating this patient, which of the following should not be given at this time to correct metabolic and electrolyte problems?

A 55-year-old male patient with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus presented with high-grade fever with chills, loin pain & tenderness over kidneys. His ultrasound shows hydroureter and hydronephrosis on the right side. What is the most appropriate management?

answers.option: Should be given I/V fluids & cranberry juice
Can be managed as outpatient on oral antibiotics
Should be admitted given I/V antibiotics and drainage by percutaneous nephrostomy
Should be given I/V antibiotics empirically

question: A 25-year-old pregnant female is advised a urine analysis and urine culture at 12 weeks of gestation. Which one of the following is correct regarding asymptomatic bacteriuria?

answers.option: More than 10³ organisms/ml is regarded as significant
Up to 10 organisms/ml is considered diagnostic
Any number of organisms is regarded as significant
More than 10⁵ organisms/ml is regarded as significant
Normal urine culture does not exclude asymptomatic bacteriuria

question: A 49-year-old male known diabetic, went for a follow-up renal check-up and reports an eGFR of 36ml/min/1.73 m². He was carrying his report from 4 months back, showing Urea: 78 mg/dL, serum creatinine 2.3 mg/dL, eGFR was 38 ml/min/1.73 m², and albumin: creatinine ratio was 300 mg/g. What will be the stage of his disease?

A 50-year-old male, a known case of diabetes mellitus and hypertension comes to the emergency department with complaints of decreased appetite, easy fatigability, and progressive shortness of breath for the last 4-5 months. On examination, blood pressure was 165/90 mm of Hg, pulse 85 beats/min, and respiratory rate 26/min. He appears pale, with periorbital puffiness and bilateral pedal edema present. Lab parameters show an Hb of 8.0 mg/dL, a normal TLC and platelet count, BUN was 60, and serum creatinine was 3.2 mg/dL. Potassium was also high. An 8-month-old report showed the same levels of deranged renal parameters. What will be the best possible diagnosis?

A 50-year old male patient with diabetes and hypertension presents to the emergency department with complaints of decreased appetite, easy fatigability, and progressive shortness of breath over the last 4-5 months. On examination, his BP was 165/90 mmHg, pulse 85/min, and respiratory rate 26/min. He appears pale, with periorbital puffiness and bilateral pedal edema. Laboratory results show Hb: 8.0 g/dL, normal TLC and platelets, BUN: 60, serum creatinine: 3.2 mg/dL, and elevated potassium. An old report from around 8 months ago shows similar levels of deranged renal parameters. What is the best possible diagnosis?

During a clinical interview, the doctor asked the patient, "What were your feelings when you were talking about a fractured arm, as you mentioned that you were a physical trainer and could easily lift ten-kilogram weights ten times?" Asking about emotions and feelings attached to various symptoms and problems is an example of which of the following?

A 45-year-old male patient has recently been diagnosed with advanced-stage stomach cancer. The doctor disclosed this news to the family and did not talk about it to the patient, as per their request. The patient later learned about it from other staff and went into shock and depression subsequently. Which of the following disclosure model, the doctor should most likely to be followed in this case?

A 32-year-old male, known to have diabetes mellitus and using alcohol occasionally, presented with loose stools (watery in consistency) for 3 days. He has been passing around 10-12 episodes every day. On examination, he was dehydrated and passing only 200 mL of urine in 24 hours. Initial investigations showed an Hb of14.8 g/dL, TLC of 11.2 x 10²/L, platelet count of 324 x 10³/L of creatinine of 4.2 mg/dL, K+ of9.4 mEq/L, HCO₃ of 18 mEq/L and urea of 94 mg/dL. Among the above-mentioned laboratory parameters, which of the following is a highly indicative marker for hemodialysis?

A 60-year-old male, a known diabetic for 8 years and taking oral hypoglycemic drugs, is admitted to the medical ICU with an altered level of consciousness. There is no history of fever, and there are no signs of meningeal irritation. Investigations reveal the following: CBC: Hb 11 g/dL, WBC 5 x 10³/mm³, Platelets 162 x 10³/mm³ RBS: 590 mg/dL Creatinine: 1.2 mg/dL Serum Sodium: 168 mg/dL Serum Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L Which of the following should not be given to this patient at this time to correct metabolic and electrolyte problems?

A 55-year-old male patient with a history of controlled diabetes mellitus presents with chills, high-grade fever, and pain and tenderness over the kidneys. Ultrasound shows right-sided hydronephrosis and hydroureter. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

answers.option: Should be given I/V antibiotics empirically
Should be admitted, given I/V antibiotics, and drainage by percutaneous nephrostomy
Should be given I/V fluids and cranberry juice
Can be managed as outpatient on oral antibiotics

question: A 49-year-old male known diabetic, went for a follow-up renal check-up and was found to have an eGFR of 36 ml/min/1.73m². He was carrying reports from 4 months ago, which showed urea levels of 78mg/dl, serum creatinine of 2.3mg/dl, eGFR of 38ml/ml/min/1.73m² and albumin:creatinine ratio of 300mg/g. What will be the stage of his disease?
